displayed_text: Patient: And I have I mean it’s a fact. But that one time was bad so then I just had it um (pause) Doctor: Okay. Yeah Patient: Two weeks ago today and it wasn’t nearly as bad. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But it’s also not seeming to work like it did. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. I hear the PSA is starting to creep up a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So how are things going since the last time I saw you a couple months ago? Patient: I’m feelin’ fine. Well, let’s put it this way… Energy, lack of energy. That’s my number one complaint. Doctor: Okay. Is that getting any better, any worse or staying the same? Patient: I - It appears to be getting worse. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds.

Patient: No, I don’t think so. Doctor: Well then next time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh the, I don’t know if they come back yet. I saw that… Patient: And I had a bone density done . And I sent that to her, I don’t know if you saw that? Doctor: Uh and G___ is what kind of doctor? Patient: Uh he’s my oncologist Patient: I’m presuming no. where I uh had the scans done Doctor: I’ll ask about it. My sense is don’t order a lot of those tests because Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you not having any bone or physical symptoms If it meets the threshold, they can give you a pill Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so

Patient: Overall, I’m feeling pretty good. Doctor: Did she grill you? Patient: Yes. She did. Doctor: Okay. Well, what are your thoughts on that horrible chemo word? Patient: You know, I’d always like, like to think it was an option of last resort but apparently we’re there. Doctor: It’s not a last resort. It’s an option. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You just have never, everything you’ve had is all pill, pill, pill, pill, and your body’s figured it out, so. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’ve got a, we’ve got to try to kill the cells another way. Patient: Sneak up on it another way. Uh. Doctor: Pretty much. Speaking of which, Dr. C___ says hi.

Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial. Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner.

Patient: I mean yeah living, dining area, a little kitchenette. You go down the hall with two bedrooms and a bathroom at the end. It’s nicer than, it’s bigger than my one at home, at home. Doctor: Oh, my, gosh. Patient: I don’t know if I still have it- Doctor: Wait a minute. So is this? Patient: B___’s house. Yeah. Doctor: This is B___’s house? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you see him or is he on tour? Patient: I saw, no, you know, he’s having some uh medical problems Doctor: Oh, no. Patient: Are we in the cone of silence here? Doctor: Well, you’re on. Hey. Could you guys, can you guys put down the thingy? The, the cut this part out? Patient: Uh, I can tell you, I can tell you when we’re walking out.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the Patient: I can give you his contact information. Doctor: Yeah, I mean he’s at B___, right? Is it at B___ – L__ at B___? Patient: I think he’s at B___ or some other. Yeah, I’m not getting the radiation. Doctor: Is he T____? Patient: No, I might have some contact information. Doctor: Uh, okay it’s like K_ (spells name)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle.

Patient: So that’s where, that’s where I thought… Family Member: That’s what we just assumed it was… Doctor: Exactly. So now we’re just being super careful that you’re aware and you’re not bungee jumping and landing on your left hip and making that hurt worse. Doctor: Yeah I know. You’re not exactly outright denying me right now the bungee jumping that you’re starting to scare me or zip lining. Doctor: Terrific. Patient: I’m just thinking, I want to ask you now, Doctor: Nothing Patient: I, I’m pleased with where we’re at. Family Member: So. Doctor: I’m gonna order the x-ray. I’m gonna send you guys over there because they’re all screaming at me. They’re gonna… Patient: Order the x-ray for? Doctor: Hip.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: -the first week of January.So, and, that’s, you know, reality is probably mid-January, I would imagine. Patient: Okay, well then… Doctor: Okay? Patient: We are leaving town on the… Family Member: The twelfth. Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then. Doctor: Okay. Let’s, we’ll incorporate that all in. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s all. Or, if we have to, then we will start the twenty-first when you come back or the twenty-second. Patient: Gotcha. Okay. Family Member: Mm-hmm.

Patient: No, no. Doctor: Ooo, it’s a little gooey under there, it is. Patient: What’s that? Doctor: A little gooey under there! Patient: Yeah. Patient: Well, that’s that the uh, ointment. Doctor: And did you see any of your blood tests and lab results? Patient: I did. Doctor: Your, uh, white count, uh, was okay. You’re less anemic than you have been, so did you get a blood transfusion or anything? Patient: No. (laughter) Doctor: Are you drinking enough fluid? You’re not dehydrated and concentrated yourself up? Patient: No.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So lots of things to throw at you. So what I’m going- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: My work is going to be to figure out what it would cost us to get on the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then this biopsy part of the trials, what, what’s required. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyway. Patient: Yeah. Uh, the last time that that you saw a spot or spots on my bone, you used radiation to go with it. Doctor: Right. Patient: So what, what’s the difference this time? Doctor: Well, I think we saw, you know, a few, you know, small number of spots. We thought like we could radiate them. Maybe those are the only spots. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: So nobody goes in? Patient: Not unless they have to pick up something. They can't stay because there's not air conditioning. The HVAC is turned off. Doctor: Holy mackerel that’s like serious. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you think you guys will ever go back someday? Hard to say? Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Uh my legs you know uh there are a couple things we talked about Doctor: Um hum. Patient: what might be going on. Uh, you know, Dr. D___, I really like, he’s a good guy. Doctor: Good guy. Right? I thought you’d like him. Patient: And he, you know, he maybe suggested maybe uh arthritis. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But it seemed like I, would have, I was degenerating pretty quickly for you know? For all the bone scans I’ve had… Doctor: Yeah. Yes. Patient: Somebody would have seen that somewhere. Doctor: No. I think it’s just crappy cancer not controlled. You know? Patient: And Uh. Yeah. Doctor: There’s, there’s the uh oh this is really going to be in trouble. We got that fixed. But it’s the bigger picture.

Patient: Yeah, that's better. The pain-- Doctor: Okay. Patient: is, the drops help on that. There's no pain, the throb it’s not there. Doctor: Alright, then now let me see though (whispering) Patient: You were just covering it a little bit there. (pause) Doctor: This one is weeping? Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok.
